snippet: Last week, in a Congressional hearing, Apple got grilled for its low-tax strategy. But not every business can copy that approach. Here is a look at what S.&P. 500 companies paid in corporate income taxes — federal, state, local and foreign — from ...

headline.main: Across U.S. Companies, Tax Rates Vary Greatly

snippet: Making a good phone isn’t enough to compete in the brutal handset market. Just ask HTC, BlackBerry, Nokia and just about any company that isn’t Apple. Chetan Sharma, an independent telecommmunications analyst who does consulting for carriers, has ...
abstract: Making a good phone isn’t enough to compete in the brutal handset market. Just ask HTC, BlackBerry, Nokia and just about any company that isn’t Apple. Chetan Sharma, an independent telecommmunications analyst who does consulting for carriers, has come up with a formula to help explain how a phone becomes a big seller or a flop in the United States.

headline.main: A Best-Selling Phone? It's Not Just a Good Phone

snippet: Original Apple-1 computers can now sell for hundreds of thousands of dollars at professional auctions. But the vintage machines have been selling informally for years. The story of the 1997 sale of an Apple-1, now residing at the Computer History ...
abstract: Original Apple-1 computers can now sell for hundreds of thousands of dollars at professional auctions. But the vintage machines have been selling informally for years. The story of the 1997 sale of an Apple-1, now residing at the Computer History Museum, shows how things worked in simpler times. That Apple-1 was a treasured prize for the young entrepreneur who bought it, and the sale was a financial lifeline for a struggling single mother.

headline.main: How Vintage Apple Computers Used to Sell

snippet: Arne Maynard’s rustic-chic house and tapestried grounds in the Welsh countryside double as guesthouse and plein-air classroom for blossoming horticulturists.
abstract: Arne Maynard’s rustic-chic house and tapestried grounds in the Welsh countryside double as guesthouse and plein-air classroom for blossoming horticulturists.

snippet: Silicon Valley’s billionaires have long been criticized for not giving away enough money, but there are signs that some, like the widow of Steve Jobs, are instead choosing to do it anonymously, and paving the way for a new type of philanthropy.
abstract: Silicon Valley’s billionaires have long been criticized for not giving away enough money, but there are signs that some, like the widow of Steve Jobs, are instead choosing to do it anonymously, and paving the way for a new type of philanthropy.

headline.main: Laurene Powell Jobs and Anonymous Giving in Silicon Valley
headline.print_headline:
Giving Quietly,
And Leaving Off
The Jobs Name

McDonald, had resigned. | Four executives of SAC Capital Advisors have received subpoenas to testify before a grand jury. | In a push to soften financial regulations, bank lobbyists are helping lawmakers draft legislation. | Congressional concern over SoftBank’s bid for Sprint Nextel is growing.

snippet: Apple-1 computers, built in Steve Jobs’s family garage, have sold for hundreds of thousands of dollars in recent auctions, a run-up reflecting the company’s mystique, Steve Lohr reports in The New York Times.

snippet: In a Senate subcommittee hearing on Apple’s avoidance of paying taxes, John McCain and others tried to point out how unfair the current system was to domestic corporations.
abstract: Floyd Norris High & Low Finance column explores tense Senate subcommittee hearing on Apple's avoidance of paying taxes, at which lawmakers asserted that current tax system is deeply unfair to domestic corporations; holds that such disparity encourages tax avoidance on wider scale; calls for tax reform that will address loopholes that allow large, multinational corporation to hide huge swaths of their earnings.

headline.main: The Corrosive Effect of Apple’s Tax Avoidance
headline.print_headline: The Corrosive Effect Of Apple’s Tax Avoidance

snippet: Apple-1 computers have sold for hundreds of thousands of dollars in recent auctions, a run-up reflecting the company’s mystique.
abstract: Models of original Apple 1 computer, sold in 1976 for $666.66, are fetching auction prices as high as $640,0000; huge increase in value has to do with economics of scarcity, technofetishism and powerful mystique surrounding Apple and its founders.
